slides.text: When’s the last time you changed your password on your email account?

slides.title: Cold Hard Facts
slides.text:
Well, 21% of internet users use passwords that they haven’t changed in 10 years!

For context, Brad Pitt and Jennifer Aniston were still together back then!

slides.title: Cold Hard Facts #2
slides.text: You’d also be surprised at what the most common passwords leaked in 2016 data breaches were...

slides.title: How many people used these passwords?
slides.text: Believe it or not, over 50% of users in these breaches used these passwords!

slides.title: Not so fast...
slides.text:
Maybe you’re telling yourself "I don’t use any of these passwords, so I should be fine."

That’s a dangerous assumption--as we’ll show you in this module, some passwords you think are secure may actually be extremely easy to crack!

slides.title: Why Secure Passwords Matter
slides.text: It’s also easy to believe that you’re not a lucrative target, and it’s hard to conceive that someone would want to break into your online accounts. It may be hard to incentivize yourself to change your password to something more secure.

slides.title: Risks of an Insecure Account
slides.text: But do you really want your account to be easily broken into, like all of those people above who had personal information leaked as a result of poor password security?

slides.title: Module Overview
slides.text: This module will teach you how easy it is to crack some passwords, in addition on tips for constructing more secure passwords. It’ll also introduce you to password managers, which generate strong passwords and save you the trouble of remembering all of them!
In this section, we’re going to show you how frequently people make passwords that are easy to guess through brute force. We’ll also show you how quick one can crack a password you think is secure!

slides.title: Password Length
slides.text: Remember how most websites prescribe a minimum password length? That’s usually 8 characters, and it turns out 61% of users create password that just meet that limit.

slides.title: Password Composition
slides.text: On average, these passwords consist of 1.1 upper-case letters, 6.1 lower-case letters, 2.2 numbers and 0.2 special characters.

slides.title: How Quick is this to Crack?
slides.text:
So, this means there are 26 lowercase letters, 26 uppercase letters, and 10 digits that most frequently are in a password (special characters are infrequent enough that we will not include them in this calculation).

26+26+10 = 62

This means there are 62^8 combinations of passwords that the typical internet user would pick from. That sounds like a LOT, right?

slides.title: Cracking is Quick!
slides.text: As of 2011, available commercial products claim the ability to test up to 2,800,000,000 passwords a second on a standard desktop computer using a high-end graphics processor. That’s a lot...

slides.question: Out of 62^8 possible password combinations, and 2,800,000,000 password tests a second, what’s the longest amount of time it would take to find out which password is yours by testing different passwords with your username? Answer in hours to one decimal place.

slides.text: Cracking your password, then, takes less than a day on a simple commercial computer--and this is using a slower 2011 personal computer and not even using the much faster processors available through cloud computing!

slides.title: The Danger of Dictionary Words
slides.text: An attacker can even speed up guessing by guessing dictionary words in your password! Instead of testing all possible combinations of letters and numbers, the attacker can run your passwords against a list of dictionary words.

slides.question: Given that there are 252,200 words in the Oxford english dictionary, and the average user uses 2 numbers in their password, how many possible password combinations are there if you use a lowercase word from the dictionary and two numbers?

Out of 25,200,000 possible password combinations, and 2,800,000,000 password tests a second, what’s the longest amount of time it would take to find out which password is yours? Answer to three decimal places.

slides.text: Seventy-five percent of passwords are simply composed of dictionary words… so the majority of passwords can be cracked under a second! Clearly the majority of internet users need to use more secure passwords.

slides.title: Check Your Password Security
slides.text: https://howsecureismypassword.net/ can tell you how long it would take for your password to get cracked. Why don’t you try it with a test password that uses the same number of lowercase, uppercase, and numeric characters that one of your passwords uses? You might be shocked with the result!
Now that we’ve learned how simple it can be to crack a weak password, it’s crucial to learn how to generate more secure ones.
Luckily, creating stronger passwords is actually not that hard. This section of the module will teach you how to make easy-to-remember, hard-to-guess passwords.

slides.title: Length Matters
slides.text: The key to designing more secure passwords is to increase their size. For example, take a password that uses uppercase letters, lowercase letters, and numeric characters. Every time a password has an extra character, it is harder to guess by a factor of (26+26+10)=62!

slides.title: Longer Passwords are Harder to Remember
slides.text: The caveat of longer passwords is that they are harder to remember. Can you imagine remembering a random 15-character password like the one on the right?

slides.question: This password, which uses special characters like “@” and “*”, now has 26 lowercase letters, 26 uppercase letters, 10 numerical characters, and 32 special characters like “@” and “*”, has how many variations? Write in scientific notation to two digits (e.g. 2.55 * 10 ^2) in the two boxes.

With 2,800,000,000 password tests a second, how long would it take to brute-force guess one of these 15-character passwords?

Write in scientific notation to two digits (e.g. 2.55 * 10 ^2) in the two boxes.

slides.text: So, a 15-character random password is clearly difficult to break via brute force. They’re also extremely difficult to remember! Let’s see if there’s an easier way to create a secure password.

slides.title: Intro to Diceware passwords
slides.text: Diceware passwords combine the best of both words: longer passwords that are more secure, but still easier to remember.

slides.title: What’s a Diceware password?
slides.text:
A diceware password has you choose six words at random. These words are selected after rolling a die five times and recording each output--for example, rolling 1, 3, 2, 2, 5 gives you the number 13225. You then look at the diceware vocabulary list and select the word corresponding to the number '13225'.

[link to diceware list: http://world.std.com/~reinhold/diceware.html]

slides.title: Example Diceware Password
slides.text: So, six numbers like 16665 15653 56322 35616 map to the password 'cleft cam synod lacy'

slides.title: QUIZ: how hard is it to crack a diceware password?
slides.question:
There are 6^5 possible words in the diceware dictionary. How many possible diceware passwords are there given that each one consists of six words?

Write in scientific notation to two digits (e.g. 2.55 * 10 ^2) in the two boxes.

slides.title: QUIZ: how hard is it to crack a diceware password?
slides.question: With 2,800,000,000 password tests a second, how long would it take to brute-force guess a six-word long diceware password?

slides.text: You’ll find that, even with four-word long diceware passwords, it would still take just under a year to brute-force one of these passwords!

slides.title: Section Conclusion
slides.text: So, we’ve learned that longer passwords are extremely secure and very difficult to brute-force. But we also have to acknowledge that even remembering a diceware password isn’t easy. What if there was an easier solution for managing long and secure passwords?
